description: Enterprise techniques used by Sakula, ATT&CK software S0074 (v1.2)
name: Sakula (S0074)

techniques.comment: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) contains UAC bypass code for both 32- and 64-bit systems.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses HTTP for C2.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

Most [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples maintain persistence by setting the Registry Run key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ in the HKLM or HKCU hive, with the Registry value and file name varying by sample.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32 and also to perform file cleanup. [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) also has the capability to invoke a reverse shell.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
Some [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples install themselves as services for persistence by calling WinExec with the net start argument.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.(Citation: Dell Sakula)

[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
Some [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) samples use cmd.exe to delete temporary files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) has the capability to download files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32.(Citation: Dell Sakula)
